body: The CDI TCK probably doesn't even have a test for this, because `default` methods were introduced in Java 8, but I agree that what you describe is what should happen. Will take a proper look tomorrow.

OK, so we actually have a test for decoration of `default` methods, which leads me to the following:

> The decorator intercepts every method which is declared by a decorated type of the decorator and is implemented by the bean class of the decorator.

Does your decorator implement the `default` methods? As in, override? If not, this exact sentence that you quoted from the specification says that they _shouldn't_ be decorated.

> OK, so we actually have a test for decoration of `default` methods, which leads me to the following:
> 
> > The decorator intercepts every method which is declared by a decorated type of the decorator and is implemented by the bean class of the decorator.
> 
> Does your decorator implement the `default` methods? As in, override? If not, this exact sentence that you quoted from the specification says that they _shouldn't_ be decorated.

In my reproducer the decorator overrides both default methods, but only get called for any invocation, if the implementing bean also overrides the decorated default method.

As mentioned in the original issue text, I would interpret this as a contradiction of the CDI full spec:
> The decorator intercepts every method which is declared by a decorated type of the decorator and is implemented by the bean class of the decorator.

The term "decorated type" is defined as:
> A decorator implements one or more bean types and intercepts business method invocations of beans which implement those bean types. These bean types are called decorated types.

In brief: Decoration is independent of what the decorated bean class overrides, and what not.

> Decoration is independent of what the decorated bean class overrides, and what not.

Sure, but it _does_ depend on what the _decorator_ bean overrides.

> Just override the default method in the decorator and return 0 without any delegating any call. Your test should fail with the actual returned value also being 0 (because the decorator hardcoded this return value), but still returning 6 as the default method is being invoked, which delegates to the abstract method, which in turn is also decorated and added 1 to the computed result.

Ah, understood! I can confirm this indeed happens and it shouldn't. I'll continue digging tomorrow.

> Sure, but it does depend on what the decorator bean overrides.

Of course :) 

If the decorator does not override a default method, I **would** expect the default method code being called ON the decoratoR instance. 
I **would NOT** expected quarkus to provide decorator bytecode for an overridden default method, which delegates the call to the decorateD instance. This would lead to different behavior, as the default method is getting called on the decorateD instance and not on the decorateR instance.

In brief: The same behavior as for programmatic decoration.

Sorry for the strange upper cases, I just wanted to stress the difference between decorator and decorated instances, because these are of course instances of different types.

issue.title: ArC: fix decorated interface defaults methods not overriden by a bean
